section.title: Using Series to Solve Differential Equations

introduction.p:
In our work in Chapter, we learned that the natural exponential function, e^x, plays a key role in the solution of several important types of differential equations. In our more recent studies in Chapter, we've learned that e^x can be represented as a Taylor series in the form
e^x = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + \cdots + c_n x^n + \cdots = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} c_k x^k . For f(x) = e^x, we know f^{(k)}(x) = e^x for every natural number k, from which it follows that f^{(k)}(0) = 1 for every k. This fact enabled us to determine the values of each coefficient c_k for the Taylor series expansion of f(x) = e^x, and hence establish that
e^x = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2!}x^2 + \cdots + \frac{1}{n!}x^n + \cdots = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k!} x^k , which is valid for every real number x.
In Preview Activity, we explore a different approach to finding the series representation of f(x) = e^x.

subsection.title: Using power series to find solutions to initial value problems
subsection.p:
In Preview Activity, we investigated the initial value problem given by y' = y, \ y(0) = 1. By assuming that the solution function y had a power series representation, we were able to write that
y = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 + c_4 x^4 + \cdots + c_n x^n + \cdots , and by finding y' and setting y' = y, see that the equation
c_1 + 2c_2 x + 3c_3 x^2 + 4c_4 x^3 + \cdots = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 + c_4 x^4 + \cdots
must hold. This led us to conclude that c_1 = c_0, 2c_2 = c_1, 3c_3 = c_2, and 4c_4 = c_3 by equating like coefficients. Since y(0) = 1 is given in the IVP and y(0) = c_0 from the series representation, it follows that c_0 = 1, and from there that c_1 = 1, c_2 = \frac{1}{2}, c_3 = \frac{1}{3 \cdot 2}, and c_4 = \frac{1}{4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2}.

This of course suggests the pattern that c_n = \frac{1}{n!}, and hence that the solution to the initial value problem is
y = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2!}x^2 + \frac{1}{3!}x^3 + \cdots + \frac{1}{n!}x^n + \cdots . Remember, we found this representation of y by solving the IVP y' = y, \ y(0) = 1, which states that y is a function whose derivative is itself and that satisfies y(0) = 1: this is precisely the function y = e^x, so our approach here has established the power series representation of f(x) = e^x from a different line of reasoning than Taylor series. Indeed, we've found that
e^x = 1 + x + \frac{1}{2!}x^2 + \frac{1}{3!}x^3 + \cdots + \frac{1}{n!}x^n + \cdots .

This approach can be used to solve a select class of other initial value problems. The key idea is to let y = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 + c_4 x^4 + \cdots + c_n x^n + \cdots, find the corresponding expression for y' (and possibly y'' and other higher derivatives if the differential equation has higher order), and then subsitute these series expresssions into the differential equation to determine relationships that must hold among the unknown coefficients, c_i. From there, using the initial condition(s), we can determine the numerical value of each c_i. We demonstrate this approach in the following example.

example.statement:
Find a power series representation for the solution to the IVP given by
y' = y-x, \ y(0) = -1 .

solution.p:
To begin, we assume that
y = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 + c_4 x^4 + \cdots , from which it follows that
y' = c_1 + 2c_2 x + 3c_3 x^2 + 4c_4 x^3 + \cdots . Setting y' = y - x, we have
c_1 + 2c_2 x + 3c_3 x^2 + 4c_4 x^3 + \cdots =\mathstrut \amp (c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 + c_4 x^4 + \cdots) - x =\mathstrut \amp c_0 + (c_1 - 1) x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 + c_4 x^4 + \cdots
Equating like coefficients, it follows that
c_1 =\mathstrut \amp c_0 2c_2 =\mathstrut \amp c_1 - 1 3c_3 =\mathstrut \amp c_2 4c_4 =\mathstrut \amp c_3 \vdots\mathstrut \amp
We can see a pattern that will continue: 5c_5 = c_4, 6c_6 = c_5, and so on. Further, we observe that by the given initial condition, y(0) = -1, we can find the value of c_0 and this will then determine the value of the other constants. In particular, since
y = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 + c_4 x^4 + \cdots , it follows y(0) = c_0, so c_0 = -1. From that, we have c_1 = c_0 = -1 as well. Next, since 2c_2 = c_1 - 1, 2c_2 = -2, so c_2 = -1. With 3c_3 = c_2, we now know c_3 = -\frac{1}{3}, and using the equation involving c_4 we see that c_4 = -\frac{1}{3 \cdot 4}. Similar reasoning shows that c_5 = -\frac{1}{3 \cdot 4 \cdot 5} and c_6 = -\frac{1}{3 \cdot 4 \cdot 5 \cdot 6}.

Thus, we have found the first several terms of the power series expansion for the function y that is the solution to the given IVP. In particular,
y = -1 - x - x^2 - \frac{1}{3}x^3 - \frac{1}{3 \cdot 4}x^4 - \frac{1}{3 \cdot 4 \cdot 5}x^5 - \frac{1}{3 \cdot 4 \cdot 5 \cdot 6}x^6 - \cdots

subsection.title: Using power series to solve higher order initial value problems
subsection.p:
Initial value problems of the form
my'' + by' + ky = 0, \ y(0) = c_1, \ y'(0) = c_2
find important applications in physics, especially in spring-mass systems; the solution y to the IVP models a mass m that hangs from a spring with spring constant k, where the damping constant is b and the mass has an initial displacement of c_1 units from equilibrium and an initial velocity of c_2. While an in-depth development of solutions to these IVPs is normally studied in a full course on differential equations, we can use power series solutions to understand some of the important basic cases.

We start with the simplest possible second-order IVP,
y'' = y, \ y(0) = 1, \ y'(0) = 1 . While we know that the solution to this IVP is y = e^x, it's instructive to see how the series solution approach confirms this. In the same way that we did with first-order equations, we let
y = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 + c_4 x^4 + \cdots + c_n x^n + \cdots , so
y' = c_1 + 2c_2 x + 3c_3 x^2 + 4c_4 x^3 + \cdots + nc_n x^{n-1} + \cdots , and now further,
y'' = 2c_2 + 3 \cdot 2 c_3 x + 4 \cdot 3 c_4 x^2 + \cdots + n (n-1) c_n x^{n-2} + \cdots . Setting y'' = y, we see that
2c_2 + 3 \cdot 2 c_3 x + 4 \cdot 3 c_4 x^2 + 5 \cdot 4 c_5 x^3 + \cdots = c_0 + c_1 x + c_2 x^2 + c_3 x^3 + c_4 x^4 + \cdots . Equating like coefficients,
2c_2 =\mathstrut \amp c_0 3 \cdot 2 c_3 =\mathstrut \amp c_1 4 \cdot 3 c_4 =\mathstrut \amp c_2 5 \cdot 4 c_5 =\mathstrut \amp c_3
and so on. We see from this chain of equalities that the even-indexed constants c_i depend on c_0, while the odd-indexed constants depend on c_1. In the original IVP statement, we were given that y(0) = 1 and y'(0) = 1, so this implies that c_0 = 1 and c_1 = 1 from the power series expansions of y and y''.

Using all of our work so far, we now see that 2c_2 = c_0 = 1, so c_2 = \frac{1}{2}; next, we have that 3 \cdot 2 c_3 = c_1 = 1, so c_3 = \frac{1}{3 \cdot 2}; similarly, 4 \cdot 3 c_4 = c_2 = \frac{1}{2}, so c_4 = \frac{1}{4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2}; and further, 5 \cdot 4 c_5 = c_3 = \frac{1}{3 \cdot 2}, so c_5 = \frac{1}{5 \cdot 4 \cdot 3 \cdot 2}. We wee the pattern that c_k = \frac{1}{k!}, which of course aligns with the fact that y = e^x is the solution to the original IVP. In the next activity, we explore several other second-order IVPs using a similar approach.
